sources.title: Wadi Bani Khalid
sources.content:
Wādī Banī Khālid (Arabic: وَادِي بَنِي خَالِد) is a wadi and a tourist attraction in Oman. Its stream maintains a constant flow of water throughout the year. Large pools of water and boulders are scattered along the course of the wadi. As a geographical area, the wadi covers a large swathe of lowland and the Hajar Mountains.
Caves form some of the features of this wadi. These include Kahf Maqal (كَهْف مَقَل), which was described as an "underground chamber" of the Sultanate of Oman, or the best out of 4,000 caves. Aflāj (underground canals) and springs are also common in this wadi, including ʿAin Ḥamūdah (عَيْن حَمُوْدَة), ʿAin aṣ-Ṣārūj (عَيْن ٱلصَّارُوْج) and ʿAin Dawwah (عَيْن دَوَّه).
It contains the Muqal Cave.

See also
List of wadis of Oman
Wadi Bani Awf


== References ==

sources.content:
## Overview
Northern Oman is the region hosting the capital city Muscat, fertile Al-Batinah coast, majestic Hajar Mountains and the Musandam Peninsula. It borders the United Arab Emirates to the north and Saudi Arabia to the west.

## Cities
23.589358.39471 Muscat — the historic capital and largest city
22.9757.29872 Bahla — oasis town with a  UNESCO World Heritage Site
24.250955.79313 Buraimi  — border crossing town adjacent to Al Ain in the United Arab Emirates
26.180356.24964 Khasab — capital of Musandam Peninsula and historic port to Iran
22.932557.53115 Nizwa — home the best-known fort in Oman
24.344756.74256 Sohar — the legendary home of Sindbad
23.218356.49247 Ibri — land of Wadis and Suqs

## Other destinations
23.171957.49961 Hajar Mountains — a majestic range, which stretches into the United Arab Emirates
25.284556.31152 Madha — tiny exclave of Oman completely surrounded by the United Arab Emirates
26.26656.49993 Musandam Peninsula  — a rocky exclave on the Straits of Hormuz with some magnificent wadis and a coastline with fjord-like fingers out into the ocean

## Get in
Muscat International Airport (MCT IATA)

## See
22.99888957.5360561 Aflaj Irrigation Systems of Oman. A world heritage site made up of five ancient irrigation systems. They are located in the regions of Ash Sharqiyah and Al Batinah, in the Hajar Mountains.
23.2756.7452 Archaeological Sites of Bat, Al-Khutm and Al-Ayn. Archaeological  UNESCO World Heritage Sites in the Hajar Mountains. UNESCO describes it as the "most complete collection of settlements and necropolises from the 3rd millennium B.C. in the world."

## Stay safe
Large areas of the south are uninhabited, and travelers should make adequate preparations for survival in a desert wilderness.
